topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: User-Provided Services

body.p: User-provided service instances allow you connect applications running on Application Lifecycle Service to specified external data services, without hard coding the credentials into the application. The service instance provides the connection information to the application via the VCAP_SERVICES environment variables, just like the built-in data services.

Think of user-provided services as a credentials database for your Application Lifecycle Service application space. You provide the connection information and ALS stores it in a JSON object which can then be bound any applications in the space.

section.title: Creating
section.p: User-provided service instances will typically be used to connect applications hosted on Application Lifecycle Service to existing external database hosts or clusters. For example, to connect an app to an externally-hosted PostgreSQL database:
section.codeblock: helion create-service user-provided prod-db-int Which credentials to use for connections [hostname, port, password]: host, port, database, user, pass host: dbhost1.example.com port: 5432 database: prod-django-321 user: ro-web pass: vsTLP2gs Creating new service ... OK
section.p: The parameter names provided in the first step will become the keys in the JSON object exposed to the application later.

section.title: Binding
section.p: Once the service instance has been created it can be bound to applications, just like any other service:
section.codeblock: helion bind-service prod-db-int django-cms Binding prod-db-int to scaling-demo ... Stopping Application [django-cms] ... OK Starting Application [django-cms] ... OK http://django-cms.helion.example.com/ deployed

section.title: Using
section.p: The helion service command will show the credentials:
section.codeblock:
helion service prod-db-int
prod-db-int +--------------+------------------------------+ | What | Value | +--------------+------------------------------+ | Type | user-provided | | Space | example::example-dev | | | | | Credentials | | | - database | prod-django-321 | | - host | dbhost1.example.com | | - pass | vsTLP2gs | | - port | 5432 | | - user | ro-web | | | | | Applications | django-cms | +--------------+------------------------------+
section.p:
The VCAP_SERVICES
variables will expose the connection information within the application container. The parameter names you provided when setting up the service instance become the keys in the prod-db-int JSON object:
To have your application use this information, parse the variable in your application code to extract the credentials at runtime. See the Language Specific Deployment documentation for examples.

Buildpacks that auto-configure applications for system-provided services can also do so for user-provided services. For example, the java buildpack will configure applications to connect to a database if the service has a name or tag with postgres, mariadb, or mysql in it. Check the buildpack's documentation or code to see exactly what it supports.

section.title: Other Environment Variables
section.p: User-provided service instances do not set DATABASE_URL or database-specific URL environment variables.
If your application uses variables in URL format, you can add them manually to the application with the set-env command. For example:
section.codeblock: helion set-env appname MYSQL_URL mysql: dbuser:pass@10.0.0.55:3306/dbname
section.p: These variables can be created whether or not user-provided service instances have been created.
